abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Market Led Smallholder
            Development in the Zambezi Valley Project for Mozambique
            were as follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory,
            global environmental objective (GEO) outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, risk to development outcome was
            substantial, risk to GEO outcome was substantial, Bank
            performance was moderately satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: the design of projects for implementation
            under decentralized arrangements, using country systems,
            should critically examine the existing capacity at all
            levels. In order to build the strong decentralization
            capacity at local, district, and national levels, the
            project should have considered a long-term approach; using
            flexible lending instruments for example, adjustable program
            loan (APL) in order to ensure consistent and continued
            support for a longer period of time than the planned five
            year period. The sustainability of community empowerment
            requires continued government follow-up, facilitating
            appropriate linkages with service providers and agribusiness
            value-chain players. There is need for clear targeting and
            beneficiary selection criteria in order to maximize project
            impact. It is always good practice to ensure that the
            targeting and beneficiary selection criteria is well spelt
            out in the project implementation manual, and that its
            application is as participatory as possible to ensure that
            it is fully understood by all stakeholders.
